S4.T2.caption: Table 2. Statistics of MIMIC-III and AmsterdamUMCdb
S4.T2.table:
MIMIC AmsterdamUMCdb OSUWMC
#. of patients 21,686 6,560 85,181
#. of male 11,862 3,412 41,710
#. of female 9,824 3,148 43,471
Age (mean ±plus-or-minus\pm± std) 60.7 ±plus-or-minus\pm± 11.6 62.1 ±plus-or-minus\pm± 12.3 59.3 ±plus-or-minus\pm± 16.1
Missing rate 65% 68% 75%
Sepsis rate 32% 35% 29%
references: Datasets. We validate our system on two publicly available datasets ( MIMIC-III2 22 22https://mimic.physionet.org/ and AmsterdamUMCdb3 33 33https://amsterdammedicaldatascience.nl) and one proprietary dataset extracted from OSUWMC4 44 44https://wexnermedical.osu.edu/. We first extracted all the sepsis patients with sepsis-3 criteria (Singer et al., 2016a) in the datasets. For each sepsis patient, we select 1 control patient with the same demographics (i.e., age and gender). We extracted 26 vital signs and lab tests from the datasets. A detailed list of clinical variables can be found in supplementary materials. The statistics of the three datasets are displayed in (Singer et al., 2016a) in the datasets. For each sepsis patient, we select 1 control patient with the same demographics (i.e., age and gender). We extracted 26 vital signs and lab tests from the datasets. A detailed list of clinical variables can be found in supplementary materials. The statistics of the three datasets are displayed in Table 2.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3. AUROC of risk prediction with the active sensing (cold-start).
S5.T3.table:
MIMIC-III AmsterdamUMCdb OSUWMC
2% 4% 6% 8% 2% 4% 6% 8% 2% 4% 6% 8%
Random Sensing 0.761 0.772 0.779 0.785 0.772 0.781 0.788 0.793 0.785 0.794 0.805 0.811
Monte Carlo 0.771 0.789 0.797 0.812 0.782 0.795 0.802 0.817 0.797 0.818 0.855 0.886
Active Learning 0.773 0.791 0.804 0.817 0.780 0.800 0.805 0.816 0.802 0.820 0.857 0.889
VAT 0.783 0.801 0.812 0.822 0.786 0.802 0.815 0.823 0.809 0.844 0.889 0.916
RASN 0.770 0.788 0.796 0.810 0.780 0.793 0.802 0.814 0.795 0.816 0.853 0.881
RASL 0.783 0.801 0.812 0.824 0.785 0.801 0.818 0.822 0.814 0.848 0.877 0.917
RAS (Ours) 0.792 0.810 0.823 0.835 0.795 0.809 0.828 0.840 0.823 0.857 0.889 0.929
references:
Table 3 displays the risk prediction performance with different active sensing ratios (i.e., 2%-8%).
With additional variables observed, all the methods can achieve more accurate prediction performance for sepsis onset.
Moreover, all the active sensing algorithms outperform the random sensing baseline with the same observation rate, which demonstrates that active sensing can improve downstream tasks’ performance.
Among the active sensing algorithms, the proposed RAS achieved the best performance with different active sensing ratios, which demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model.

We have three versions of the framework. RAS N directly uses the gradient to estimate propagated uncertainty. RAS N directly uses the gradient to estimate propagated uncertainty. RAS L uses a linear regularization term to make the model locally smooth, while RAS uses adversarial training. For RAS L uses a linear regularization term to make the model locally smooth, while RAS uses adversarial training. For RAS L and RAS versions, the additional terms change the loss functions. We conduct experiments to show whether the additional terms can improve model training. We train the three versions of models independently and test them on all the observed data (without active sensing). As L and RAS versions, the additional terms change the loss functions. We conduct experiments to show whether the additional terms can improve model training. We train the three versions of models independently and test them on all the observed data (without active sensing). As Table 4 shows, RAS L and RAS outperform RAS L and RAS outperform RAS N , which demonstrates local linearity can further improve prediction performance. With adversarial training, RAS can achieve better local linearity than RAS N, which demonstrates local linearity can further improve prediction performance. With adversarial training, RAS can achieve better local linearity than RAS L and thus perform the best, which also explains why the RAS outperforms better than Monte-Carlo sampling in L and thus perform the best, which also explains why the RAS outperforms better than Monte-Carlo sampling in Table 3 in the active sensing.

A1.T6.caption: Table 6. AUROC of risk prediction of the propose RAS with different backbones.
A1.T6.table:
MIMIC-III AmsterdamUMCdb OSUWMC
2% 4% 6% 8% 2% 4% 6% 8% 2% 4% 6% 8%
FC 0.760 0.772 0.782 0.792 0.772 0.785 0.792 0.801 0.785 0.801 0.823 0.841
RNN 0.782 0.790 0.810 0.821 0.787 0.799 0.816 0.825 0.814 0.842 0.873 0.910
GRU 0.789 0.799 0.822 0.833 0.792 0.806 0.826 0.837 0.821 0.855 0.887 0.928
LSTM 0.792 0.81 0.823 0.835 0.795 0.809 0.828 0.840 0.823 0.857 0.889 0.929
references: We also conduct more experiments with different backbones (e.g., RNN, GRU, FC) and display the performance in Table 6 in subsection A.3. The experimental results show that the proposed model can consistently improve the prediction performance for all the backbones by recommending the most informative variables for observation.

Our model is applicable to various models, including LSTM, GRU, and fully-connected networks (FC). LSTM has shown superior performance in modeling clinical time series data in multiple tasks, including missing value imputation (Yin et al., 2019; Yan et al., 2019), clinical prediction (Yin et al., 2019; Yan et al., 2019), clinical prediction (Men et al., 2021), and patient subtyping (Men et al., 2021), and patient subtyping (Baytas et al., 2017), so we choose LSTM as the model backbone. We also conducted more experiments with different backbones as shown in (Baytas et al., 2017), so we choose LSTM as the model backbone. We also conducted more experiments with different backbones as shown in Table 6. The experimental results show that the proposed model can significantly improve the prediction performance for all the backbones by recommending the most informative variables for observation.
